newsitem.title: USA: U.S. DOLLAR "A BIT TOO HIGH"--U.S. MANUFACTURERS.
newsitem.headline: U.S. DOLLAR "A BIT TOO HIGH"--U.S. MANUFACTURERS.

text.p: The U.S. dollar is "a bit too high" but is likely to recede from its current level some time next year, a key U.S. industrialists' group said on Thursday.

"The dollar is a bit too high in my judgement and I'd like to see it somewhat lower," Jerry Jasinowski, President of the National Association of Manufacturers, told Reuters Financial Television in an interview.
"I wouldn't be at all surprised for the dollar in 1998 to come down some," he added. Jasinowski declined to specify a target range for the dollar.
The dollar last traded at around 1.8680 to the German mark, while the Japanese yen was around 118.25 to the dollar.
Jasinowski told a news briefing earlier on Thursday that the strong dollar was not yet a major concern for U.S. exporters, because its effects were partly offset by modest economic growth in Europe.
"Modest growth in Europe to some extent offsets the higher dollar. It's not something that has manufacturing firms really up in arms now," he said.
A stronger dollar can potentially hurt exports by making U.S. goods more expensive abroad. ((--Washington newsroom 202 898 8377))
